tn.ref: she received approval in his eyes
tn.text: The word "eyes" refers to his sight and is a metaphor for his evaluation of her. This can be stated in active form. AT: "he was pleased with her" or "he approved of her" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: He held out to her the golden scepter in his hand
tn.text: He did this to show that he he was pleased with her.

tn.ref: touched the tip of the scepter
tn.text: She probably did this to to show that she respected his authority and was thankful for his kindness to her.

tn.ref: Up to half of my kingdom, it will be given to you
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "If you ask for up to half of my kingdom, I will give it to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: If it pleases the king, let the king and Haman come ... for him
tn.text: In order to show respect to a king, people sometimes did not call him "you." This can be translated with the word "you" along with other words that show respect. AT: "O King, if it pleases you, come and bring Haman ... for you" or "If you are willing to do this, Sir, come, and let Haman come with you .. for you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
Translate this man's name as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:est:03:01|3:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
The abstract noun "petition" can be expressed with the verb "ask for" or "want"? AT: "What do you ask for?" or "What do you want?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This can be expressed in active form. AT: "I will give you what you ask for" or "I will do for you what you ask" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The abstract noun "request" can be expressed with the verb "ask for" or "want"? AT: "What do you ask for?" or "What do you want?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: Up to half of the kingdom, it will be granted
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "If you ask for up to half of my kingdom, I will give it to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

The words "petition" and "request" mean the same thing. She probably used these words together as a way of speaking very formally and respectfully to the king. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: if I have found favor in the eyes of the king
tn.text: "Find favor" is an idiom that means be approved of or that he is pleased with her. "In the eyes of the king" is a metaphor representing his evaluation. AT: "if the king evaluates me and approves" or "if the king is pleased with me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: if I have found favor in the eyes of the king and if it pleases the king
tn.text: In order to show respect to a king, people sometimes did not call him "you." This can be translated with the word "you" along with other words that show respect. AT: "if you are pleased with me, O King, and if it pleases you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: Let the king and Haman come
tn.text: This can be translated with the word "you" along with other words that show respect. AT: "Please come and bring Haman" or "Please come and let Haman come with you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: and I will answer the king's question
tn.text: This can be translated with the word "you" along with other words that show respect. AT: "and I will answer your question" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
Rising was a sign of respect. Mordecai did not give Haman special respect. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
Being "filled with rage" represents being very angry. AT: he was extremely angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This can be translated with a phrase. "Even though he was so angry"

Restraining himself represents refusing to do something that he wanted very much to do. Haman wanted to show Mordecai that he was very angry. AT: "Haman refused to show how angry he was" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is a woman's name. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Haman recounted to them the splendor of his riches
tn.text: "Splendor" and "riches" are both abstract nouns. AT: "Haman told them about how great his wealth was" or "Haman told them about the many great things he owned" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: all the promotions by which the king honored him
tn.text: The abstract noun "promotion" can be expressed with the verb "promote." It means that the king gave him more important work. AT: "How the king had promoted him many times and honored him" or "how the king had honored him many times by giving him more important work" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: how he had advanced above all the officials and the servants of the king
tn.text: Advancing above people represents becoming more important than them. AT: "how he had become more important than all the officials and the servants of the king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This can be expressed positively. AT: "only me"
"does not make me happy" or "does not satisfy me"

a structure used for killing a person by tying one end of a a rope around the top of the structure and the other end of the rope around the person's neck and hanging him from it. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:est:02:22|2:23]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
"50 cubits high." You may convert this to a modern measure. AT: "twenty-three meters high" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bdistance]])
"he told people to construct the gallows"
"Haman liked this idea"
